prerequisites.title: Threat Vectors
prerequisites.why_needed: Social engineering is a key human attack vector

unlocks.title: Security Awareness
unlocks.connection: Awareness training defends against social engineering

daily_tasks: Determine if incident started with social engineering

introduction.hook: In 2020, a 17-year-old didn't use zero-day exploits to breach Twitter. He simply called employees, convinced them he was from IT, and talked them into giving up credentials. Within hours, he controlled accounts of Obama, Elon Musk, and Biden""posting scams to 350 million followers. The most powerful security technology is worthless when humans can be convinced to bypass it.
learning_goals: Identify social engineering techniques: phishing, pretexting, baiting
Recognize psychological principles attackers exploit: authority, urgency, social proof
Differentiate phishing variants: spear phishing, whaling, smishing, vishing

why_it_matters.career_impact: You'll design awareness programs, test users with simulated attacks, and implement technical controls.
why_it_matters.business_connection: Social engineering is involved in over 90% of successful attacks. Every employee is a potential target.
why_it_matters.exam_relevance: Expect 8-10 questions on techniques, psychology, and defenses.

sections.title: Social Engineering Psychology

content.overview: Social engineering exploits human psychology rather than technical vulnerabilities. Understanding the psychological principles is key to defense.

principles.description: People comply with perceived authority figures
principles.example: I'm from IT and need your password
Your account will be closed in 24 hours
Other employees have already completed this
I helped you, now help me

principles.description: People comply with those they like
People want to be consistent with prior actions

stages.description: Gather information about target from social media, company sites
Build rapport, establish credibility, create believable scenario
Cover tracks, maintain access if needed

what_would_happen_if.scenario: What if an attacker combined multiple psychological principles?
what_would_happen_if.consequence: Most effective attacks combine principles. 'This is Mike from IT (authority), we detected unusual activity (fear), and your account will be suspended in one hour (urgency). Other employees on your team have already verified (social proof).' Layered manipulation is harder to resist.

memory_hooks.mnemonic: AURSLL - Authority, Urgency, Reciprocity, Social proof, Liking, Legit-looking (consistency)

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking only gullible people fall for social engineering
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Anyone can be manipulated under the right circumstances. Stress, distraction, and urgency affect everyone..
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Anyone can be manipulated under the right circumstances. Stress, distraction, and urgency affect everyone.

mnemonics.mnemonic: AURUS = Authority, Urgency, Reciprocity, social proof, Scarcity

must_remember_for_exam.fact: Six principles: Authority, Urgency, Social proof, Reciprocity, Liking, Consistency
Authority and Urgency are most commonly exploited
Research/reconnaissance is first step in social engineering

key_points: Social engineering targets human psychology, not technology
Six principles: authority, urgency, social proof, reciprocity, liking, consistency
Attack cycle: research â†' develop trust â†' exploit â†' exit

knowledge_check.question: An attacker says: 'This is Mike from IT. Unusual activity detected. Your access will be suspended in one hour unless you verify credentials now.' Which principles?
knowledge_check.explanation: Authority (claiming to be IT) and urgency (one-hour deadline). Time pressure prevents careful thinking.

wrong_answer_analysis.why_wrong: No favor being returned (reciprocity) or rapport building (liking)
No mention of others (social proof) or prior actions (consistency)
Scarcity involves limited availability; no favor for reciprocity

sections.title: Phishing Attack Variants

content.overview: Phishing uses fraudulent communications to trick victims. Multiple variants target different channels and audiences.

red_flags: Sender address doesn't match claimed organization
Requests for credentials or sensitive data

core_concepts.technique: Register domains similar to legitimate ones
core_concepts.purpose: Credential harvesting sites that look legitimate

memory_hooks.mnemonic: PSWSV: Phishing (mass), Spear (targeted), Whaling (executives), Smishing (SMS), Vishing (Voice)

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking spear phishing is just better phishing
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Spear phishing involves specific research about the target""their role, relationships, current projects. It's personalized..
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Spear phishing involves specific research about the target""their role, relationships, current projects. It's personalized.

must_remember_for_exam.fact: Phishing = mass, Spear Phishing = targeted, Whaling = executives

key_points: Phishing variants: mass phishing, spear phishing (targeted), whaling (executives)
Typosquatting creates lookalike domains for credential theft

knowledge_check.question: An attacker sends personalized emails to CFOs of multiple companies, referencing their specific industry and recent news. This is:
knowledge_check.explanation: Whaling targets executives specifically. While personalized like spear phishing, targeting C-suite makes it whaling.

wrong_answer_analysis.why_wrong: Standard phishing is mass/generic, not personalized
Spear phishing is targeted but whaling specifically targets executives

sections.title: In-Person Social Engineering

content.overview: Physical social engineering attacks exploit human politeness and trust in person.

techniques.description: Following someone through a secure door without badging
Same as tailgating but with victim's knowledge/consent

types.access_gained: Various areas depending on claimed role

what_would_happen_if.scenario: What if someone in a delivery uniform asked you to hold the door?
what_would_happen_if.consequence: Most people would hold it""politeness overrides security. Attackers exploit this constantly. Security awareness must overcome natural helpfulness in specific situations.

memory_hooks.mnemonic: TPSD - Tailgating, Piggybacking, Shoulder surfing, Dumpster diving (physical attacks)

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Tailgating = victim unaware. Piggybacking = victim knows but allows it (holds door open)..
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Tailgating = victim unaware. Piggybacking = victim knows but allows it (holds door open).

must_remember_for_exam.fact: Dumpster diving = searching trash for info

key_points: Dumpster diving targets poor document disposal

knowledge_check.question: Someone carrying boxes asks an employee to hold the door. The employee holds it, and the person enters without badging. This is:
knowledge_check.explanation: Piggybacking""the employee knowingly allows entry by holding the door. Tailgating would be following closely without the employee's awareness.

wrong_answer_analysis.why_wrong: Tailgating is following without victim's awareness""here the employee actively helped
Shoulder surfing is observing credential entry, not physical access
Pretexting is creating a false scenario for information, not physical access

sections.title: Other Social Engineering Techniques

content.overview: Additional techniques beyond phishing and physical access.

core_concepts.definition: Creating a fabricated scenario to manipulate victim
examples: Posing as vendor conducting a survey
Claiming to be from HR updating records
core_concepts.key_element: The pretext (false story) must be believable

core_concepts.definition: Offering something enticing to lure victim
examples: USB drives in parking lot labeled 'Confidential'
Fake job offers requiring personal info

core_concepts.definition: Compromise websites frequently visited by targets
core_concepts.example: Compromising industry news site to target finance professionals

core_concepts.definition: Offering a service in exchange for information
core_concepts.example: Calling employees offering IT help in exchange for their credentials

must_remember_for_exam.fact: Watering hole = compromising sites targets visit
Quid pro quo = something for something

key_points: Watering hole compromises frequently visited sites
Quid pro quo offers services for information

sections.title: Defending Against Social Engineering

content.overview: Defense requires both technical controls and human awareness training.

controls.function: Stolen credentials alone don't grant access

defenses.approach: Test and reinforce with fake attacks
Call back on known numbers, verify requests

must_remember_for_exam.fact: MFA defeats credential theft from phishing
Phishing simulations test and reinforce training

key_points: Technical: email filtering, DMARC, web filtering, MFA
Human: awareness training, phishing simulations, reporting culture
MFA is critical""stolen passwords alone don't work

key_takeaways: Social engineering exploits psychology: authority, urgency, social proof, reciprocity, liking, consistency
Phishing variants: mass phishing, spear (targeted), whaling (executives), smishing (SMS), vishing (voice)
Physical attacks: tailgating (unaware), piggybacking (aware), shoulder surfing, dumpster diving
Pretexting creates false scenarios; baiting uses enticement (USB drops)
Defense requires technical controls AND awareness training
exam_essentials: Six psychological principles: Authority, Urgency, Social proof, Reciprocity, Liking, Consistency
Phishing = mass, Spear phishing = targeted, Whaling = executives
